s.text: Indeed, the paper points out high up that the overwhelmingly white state is hardly representative of the nation.

The NYT describes an "ebullient" Gore and immediately points up the contrast with his 1988 presidential campaign when he skipped the caucuses, calling them "madness," and referred to "the small state of Iowa."

The NYT describes an "ebullient" Gore and immediately points up the contrast with his 1988 presidential campaign when he skipped the caucuses, calling them "madness," and referred to "the small state of Iowa."

The NYT describes an "ebullient" Gore and immediately points up the contrast with his 1988 presidential campaign when he skipped the caucuses, calling them "madness," and referred to "the small state of Iowa."
On the Republican side, the paper says that Bush got 41 percent, Steve Forbes 30 percent, Alan Keyes 14 percent, and Gary Bauer 9 percent.

But if you read the fine print stashed in a couple of the piece's crannies, you learn that "next generation" and "hit home" are rather off: the furthest available projections posit that by the year 2017, a whopping 5 percent of all deaths would be subject to the tax.
Indeed, the paper points out high up that the overwhelmingly white state is hardly representative of the nation.
The NYT says that Gore outpolled Bill Bradley 63 percent to 35 percent, adding that this result was a "setback" for Bradley, "who had campaigned aggressively."
